title: Sensibo is a bank account life saver!
text: We live in Northwestern Costa Rica where it is HOT year round. Central air conditioning is not a thing here and all buildings that are air conditioned have mini split units. These are fine because if a unit goes down it means just that room is down until you can get it fixed. The downside to these units is that there is no way to have a temperature based auto on/off like with a thermostat so at night you go to bed and wake up freezing then turn it off and wake up a while later sweating from heat or the AC just runs all night long. We have 4 sensibo units in our home (1 for each AC unit) and 2 in our business. We use the climate react feature to set an upper end limit to switch the unit on in a given room and a lower end limit to switch the unit off. We sleep better at home and when we are busy at work it keeps the temperature comfortable for our clients without any attention from us. Maintaining a temperature range means the ac units aren‚Äôt running as much and our bank accounts have noticed - can‚Äôt recommend enough!

title: Super Confusing UX for Mini-Split controller
text:
I can only assume the UX designer is thoroughly frustrated because nobody listens to them and their app is a confusing disaster because of it. 

The main problem is it‚Äôs impossible to tell what happens when you leave the geofencing area. You have two options. Turn the heat off, which will presumably freeze the pipes in a couple hours, or Climate React which costs money, also turns off, and has zero explanation what is supposed to happen anyway.  It would make a lot more sense for a smart temperature control feature to turn ON and then have a temperature range ‚Äî instead, leaving the geofencing area turns things off and there‚Äôs basically no clarity as to what happens when you leave home. 

Also the UI is a little wonky, but that‚Äôs a very minor complaint to seemingly being unable to fulfill the main purpose of the hardware. 

Branding looks nice though. Cool monster illustration.

EDIT: I‚Äôve contacted support and apparently it‚Äôs not designed to maintain a more energy efficient temperature when you leave. If I want it to be 60¬∞ when I leave in the winter and 72¬∞ when I‚Äôm home... I have to manually set it every single time. That‚Äôs the only reason I bought this and why I bought the annual subscription. Took me 20min to realize this product seemed wrong, and a few days to verify it‚Äôs not possible to do anything I need it to.

title: Gradually become more disappointing

My complaint is that it does not work when I need it! Unresponsive, lagging, errors‚Ä¶ For instance, climate react option is a joke. It fails to work correctly about 1 out of 10 times - it‚Äôs a big failure rate. When it fails, rooms are left either very cold or hot because sensibo was supposed to turn off or on but does not! Log history says it sent a signal that did not change the state. Urgh!!!!! Unfortunately, I feel that the failure rate is gradually becoming worse not better. Climate react is just one of many fail examples. I used to love sensibo devices and strongly recommend them to my friends, but not any more.

title: Great but big gaps.
text:
It‚Äôs great to have a solution for remotely managing ductless ac/heat pumps. 

Setup is easy, especially compared to other options available on the market. 

It works for the core function of being able to control multiple heads without traipsing through the house to do so with the wireless remotes that came with my ac. 

2 stars. Not because they don‚Äôt work as advertised but because the cons are so annoying over time. 

The other thermostats I had before this had this capability but when they failed, you could plan on spending around an hour navigating a complex setup process that if you mis-stepped once, you had to start over at the beginning. Sensibo does NOT have this problem. 

Cons
If you have more than one head for a ductless system, the app doesn‚Äôt have a universal on/off capability. 

It could also benefit from a smart feature that automatically runs the fan after air conditioning to help dry out the system. 

The paid app upgrade features are marginally helpful but way overpriced. I‚Äôd consider $2.99 a year but they‚Äôre greedy and want 12x that per year for content that comes free with the Apple weather app. 

The thermostat and hydrometer are not accurate out of the box. Instead one has to rely on yet another thermostat to correctly calibrate the thermostats to the correct room temperature and humidity. 

With four heads across three floors of my house, I am getting carpal tunnel having to set the same settings for four different thermostats every time I want/need to make a change. 

I don‚Äôt know if the newer thermostats that were released in the past year improve on any of these issues. I‚Äôm not inclined to spend another $500 to test them out.

title: Great Hardware Needs UX help
text:
I‚Äôve been using Sensibo to controller my air source heat pump for about 6 months.  It does a great job of letting me control my system to a tighter temperature control band than the built in LG control system. 

My basic heating need/program:
Set my system temp to a desired target temp in the morning, crank it up a bit before bed. Then set it down at night. 

My LG heat pump system thermostat doesn‚Äôt have a schedule, and it‚Äôs only got +-2 degrees of control resolution in heating which is terrible for comfort. 

Sensibo can save the day with climate react and scheduling. Sounds easy, right? Well you have to do a lot of settings programming to get this to work. When you get it setup it will deliver. But you will sometimes get random bugs, like all your schedules disabling themselves. The biggest issue is there is no master control to turn off the system. If I power off the system from the main app window, it just turns it off for right now, my schedules will still come in and change everything climate react will still come in and change everything.  So if I want to do the equivalent of ‚ÄúSystem Off‚Äù that my Honeywell thermostat will do, I have to go to the main app and turn off the unit, go into my schedule and disable all three schedules, go into climate react settings and turn off climate react. It‚Äôs like the developer got basic functions working initially and then bolted on feature after feature without thinking about how a user wants to interact with a heating system. It‚Äôs February, I‚Äôm in heating mode yesterday was extra warm. How do I just turn my system off?
Also how is this going to work in the Summer? Three more climate react schedules where I have 7:00am,7:00pm,10:00pm for heating mode and 7:01am,7:01pm,10:01pm for cooling? And I guess I just remember that‚Äôs how it works? God help me explaining this to my family. 

So I‚Äôm really glad the Temperature controls and readout have 0.1F of resolution or the system would be useless to me. But I‚Äôm really disappointed that they charge a monthly fee for the basic feature of nightly setbacks, and then they execute it so poorly.

title: Good idea, base tech is there, interactive control is council at best and APP is super buggy
text: Have used Sensibo for years - great idea to take a relatively basic AC control and it make it ‚Äòsmarter‚Äô. Their recent products are the 2.0 evolution of concept - adding more intelligence like climate react and presence detection - making the system even ‚Äòsmarter‚Äô. But the execution on these new features is lacking - the design to make these new capabilities work is very clunky - more like programming an IFTTT set of instructions than a simple ‚ÄòI want to do this‚Äô guided experience. The average consumer is not going to want the hassle of figuring out how to take multiple settings, put them together, and make it work.  On top of that - it does not consistently work - so you can program in schedules but then they randomly disable themselves. So not only is there the confusing interface design but then you have to figure out is it your ‚Äòprogram‚Äô that is not working or their application that is not working again. Adding one more layer to the frustration is after buying the system, they try and upsell on more ‚Äòadvanced features‚Äô that cost you more money, greater interface complexity to use, and even more frustration at the realization that the extra money you spent is a further waste as it does not actually work consistently! The product has a great technology base but time to go back to the drawing board to actually make it useful and consistent for the consumer.

title: Unbelievably good!!!
text:
Sensibo is the absolute best! Not only did it turn my dumb air conditioner into a smart AC, the Sensibo app is a delight to use. I cannot get over how well-built the app is.

Factors I love about Sensibo:
- Dark mode! No blinding myself when I turn on my AC for sleeping at night.
- It‚Äôs fast! I don‚Äôt need to wait for ever for the app to open, to save settings, or to switch between screens.
- Schedules: This feature is BEAUTIFUL. I use schedules to adjust the temperature throughout the night so that my odd body temperature swings don‚Äôt wake me up. The feature also helps wake me up as I can turn off the AC before my alarm so that the room is not too cold when I get out of bed. When choosing a time for an event, I love the odd time dial. It‚Äôs quirky and unlike anything I‚Äôve ever used before, but it‚Äôs quick and efficient.
- The Events screen, the abundant settings available, and the Climate React feature are all excellent parts of Sensibo.

I am at a loss as to why this app doesn‚Äôt have 5,000 5-star reviews. Sensibo has been 100% reliable. Both the hardware and the software are remarkably well-built. There isn‚Äôt an element of Sensibo that I do not enjoy or appreciate.

If you own an air conditioning system and you don‚Äôt use Sensibo, you are missing out.

title: privacy invasion: app wants to know where you live or refuses to setup!
text:
in response to the developer response:
I am not interested in Location Awareness mode. It should not be opt-in by default. The proper way of handling this is after account creation, or at least by giving the option to turn it on during the initial process. Making it mandatory is invasive, and for people who don't know any better or don't care about personal privacy. I am looking for alternatives at the moment. Perhaps a Raspberry Pi with a DHT22 sensor and IR controller or other product.

original review:
I just need to control an old ac when it gets hot. Why is it mandatory for you to have location services turned on before you can do anything? This is so intrusive! title: Works well, but needs an "Away" or "Vacation" function
text: I like the product and the app. Works very well with my Bryant split unit. I like the ability to set various schedules and they work nicely too. What would make this a great app is if they could add a simple "vacation" or "away" feature. Presently the only way to do that is to go into the app and turn off each individual schedule - and then turn each back on when you return. As well, a universal "heat" and "cool" setting. Day temps vary rather a lot so I don't like the auto setting, which means I have to set separate schedules for heating and cooling and then turn the right ones on or off depending on time of year. If that is too challenging, at least make the summary in the app to where you can see which schedule is Heat or Cool so I don't have to open each schedule to see which is which. You're almost on to something!

title: 3.3: In a "major update", app took several iterations to be fixed, now good
text:
Earlier versions worked fine. Basic, but it worked. 3.3 fixes that. It won't even start anymore.

I'd have rather you supported mode-specifc settings of various A/C & remote pairs (which is where your software really falls down) than do a major rework that chokes on app load.

UPDATE: Removed the app. Rebooted the phone. Installed 3.3.1 - we're back to the pretense of "working". On first touch, I sharply dislike the new UI/UX.

UPDATE 2: Getting used to the UI. No more horrible than the original one. Second star for correctly modeling my remote unit. Finally. Third star for tying into Homekit for GeoFencing. Finally.

UPDATE 3: 3.3.4 seems to fix most of the remaining bugs. It‚Äôs actually a 4-star app now. Geofencing needs a little more polish, the interface for temperature-triggered settings is still a tad clunky(but you‚Äôll use it rarely once set up). But it‚Äôs a good app now. And, in this version, it hasn‚Äôt yet ‚Äúlost‚Äù a command to the unit, whether manual or automatic - which was the last of my serious issues.

title: HomePod support completely broken in new version
text:
Have had Sensibo for a few years now and WAS pretty happy with it‚Äôs Siri Shortcuts integration which allowed me to use my HomePod to set pre-configured temperatures using commands like ‚ÄúHey Siri turn on the AC‚Äù; as long as my iPhone was at home all worked great. 

With this update the HomePod now replies to these commands with ‚Äúyou‚Äôll need to continue on your iPhone‚Äù, which then pops up a Siri notification on my phone that reads ‚ÄúHomePod needs wants to help with that‚Äù, upon tapping the notification it launches the Sensibo App and finally completes the command. 

This update is just plain awful if you want to use Siri. It makes using Siri more work than just controlling your AC from the app. 

If I could downgrade to the previous working version of this app I would in a heartbeat.

Incredibly disappointed with Sensibo for releasing a buggy and broken version of this app that has broken its core functionality in exchange for a fresh coat of paint.

title: Difficult and buggy
text: The setup wasnt easy, and Im pretty computer savvy.  The app kept saying the ac was on when it was off and vice versa.  The climate react button crashes the app leading to a gray screen.  Also the app said the unit was at 75 degrees when in fact it was at 68 degrees.  I bought this to keep my pets alive at home when Im gone in the heat.  Im not inclined to trust it with their lives.  Will probably look for more stable options.  Changed my review from two stars to one because they have no phone support at all - only email, and that is slow.  Seems like they are not competing on the professional arena.

title: Not a fan of the update
text:
I love being able to control my ductless mini split from my phone. The old version of the app seemed to function better. I could turn it on and set the timer to shut off in a couple hours as I needed. Now I have to hunt for the timer. 

The bigger problem is that the thermostat doesn‚Äôt seem to work. I may set it for 75¬∞, but it keeps on cooling down to 67¬∞!  What‚Äôs the point of having anything other than on/off?

title: It works
text:
The APP itself does what it is supposed to. From the app I can switch the AC on/off, increase/decrease temperature, set heating/cooling and set the fan speed high/low. 

I did run into trouble setting up my AC with sensibo. I had to manually choose the AC from the list on their website. The description of the ACs on the list could have been better. 

An improvement could be to be able to manually add AC from the APP.

title: New version is snappier
text:
Update: 20 July 2020
The app is faster. The company listened to my but reports and acted very fast to fix them, and also followed up, making sure my experience was a good one.
Will update to 5 start when homekit is compatible out of the box.

This 2020 version is faster than the previous one which makes it feel more stable.
I can't seem to be able to place my 5 sky units in the order I want though.

It would be nice to have a dark mode, as the more contrast interface make it really hard to read in low light and bright environments.

title: Needs better IR controls
text:
If your AC unit can tell Sensibo what its current settings is, it‚Äôs probably a great device. However, I can never rely on this thing to send sequential IR commands at a pace that my GE AC is sure to receive, so this leaves the AC almost always out of sync with the app.

I‚Äôve emailed them before to simply put in the ability to slow down the commands to ensure the AC works, but they ‚Äútook it under advisement‚Äù. So now I only use it to turn it on and off, and manually increment the temperature myself.

title: Works but clunky
text:
I am using one with a GE window unit.
* It can‚Äôt remember that I‚Äôm in Fahrenheit. I have to change it every time I open it to get the readings.
* The temp ranges don‚Äôt line up with the unit‚Äôs.
* When a schedule adjusts the temp, it sends the IR codes too fast and the unit misses some which gets the temp control out of sync. 
* The unit doesn‚Äôt have a Power on or Power off control. Just power toggle, so it can get out of sync if changed outside of the app, but that isn‚Äôt Sensibo‚Äôs fault.

title: Mixed feelings
text: I have mixed feelings about this product. The app is simple and I like the UI but it's very buggy. A good example is when the temp changes from Fahrenheit  to Celsius by itself and won't change back to its previous setting. It works 80% of the time- I find myself checking the ac/heater to see if the unit actually turned on and 20% it is not. A lot of times, the system doesn't work at all and my solution is to reset everything and start over which sometimes works.

The app keeps changing the type of unit it is displaying between Celsius and Fahrenheit forcing you to keep changing it back in the settings.

Not compatible with the majority of home automation platforms.

Hardware is overpriced for what it is.

Requires connection to their server which tracks your data.

The sleep timer user interface needs improvement. Right now it requires you to circle your finger around the control once for each hour you want to add. Very tedious.

It‚Äôs good enough to do the basic job it was designed to I guess. It makes controlling your AC more convenient. There are no connection issues.

title: Nice product, HORRIBLE app
text:
I have four Sensibo Air units in my house, and besides the ongoing lack of promised HomeKit integration (which I work around with HomeBridge) I've been really pleased with my purchases. Until now. 

The latest version of the app is absolutely HORRIBLE. Besides being ugly (which I admit comes down to personal preference), they've made shortcuts completely useless now. Not Siri Shortcuts, but shortcuts - the kind you can put on your lock screen, etc. Even with 'Open app when run' unchecked, the app has to open every time you try to execute a "shortcut," which turns what USED to be a simple thing (iPhone laying on the desk, tap the screen to wake it, slide to the right, hit the shortcut button to turn on/off the A/C) into a much more complicated procedure: iPhone laying on the desk, tap the screen to wake it, slide to the right, hit the shortcut button to turn on/off the A/C, get a passcode prompt to unlock the phone, pick up the phone to initiate FaceID scan, wait for the passcode screen to come up because you didn't scan your face fast enough, unlock the phone, wait for the Sensibo app to open, wait for the "shortcut" to execute. 

Am I the only one who thinks this is absurd? Better yet, didn't Sensibo's developers actually TEST the app before releasing it? This is ridiculous. (Yes, I know, first-world problems. But I DID spend hundreds of dollars on my Sensibo setup, and having its functionality nerfed like this, a year later, is incredibly irritating)

THEY REMOVED A CORE FUNCTION AND WANT TO FORCE YOU TO SUBSCRIBE.  In my book, this is called ‚Äúextortion‚Äù.  I am NOT satisfied with this answer.

‚Äî original review ‚Äî

Sort by recent reviews, and ignore the ones on July 20 that are obviously made by a PR firm trying to cover for them.
